title: Identify Function Properties from Graphs
question: Create an interactive diagram game where undergraduate students identify mathematical function properties by examining graph descriptions: determine whether functions are injective (one-to-one), surjective (onto), bijective, continuous, or differentiable, and identify key features like critical points, inflection points, vertical and horizontal asymptotes, and intervals of increase and decrease.

blueprint.title: Function Explorer: Graph Unveiled
blueprint.subject: Mathematics
blueprint.narrativeIntro: Welcome, intrepid mathematician! Your mission is to navigate the complex landscapes of mathematical functions. By analyzing their graphs, you'll uncover their hidden properties, identify critical landmarks, and map their behavior. Prepare to explore the visual language of calculus and advanced function theory!
blueprint.completionMessage: Congratulations, Function Cartographer! You have successfully charted the intricate properties of various mathematical functions, demonstrating a profound understanding of their graphical representations and underlying principles.

diagram.assetPrompt: A clear, two-dimensional graph of a single function on a coordinate plane, rendered with precise lines. The graph must distinctly display: a jump discontinuity (a clear break where the function value 'jumps'), a sharp corner (cusp) or a point with a vertical tangent (where the function is continuous but not differentiable), a segment that is visibly smooth and continuous (and thus differentiable), and another segment that is continuous but contains a sharp corner or vertical tangent (making it not differentiable at that specific point). The overall composition should allow for clear interactive zones around these specific points and segments.

zones.label: Continuous & Differentiable Segment
zones.description: This segment represents where the function's value changes smoothly and predictably, allowing for a consistently defined instantaneous rate of change at every point along its path.

zones.label: Continuous, Not Differentiable Segment
zones.description: This segment shows where the function's value remains unbroken, yet its instantaneous rate of change undergoes an abrupt, non-smooth shift, preventing a unique tangent from being defined at specific points.

config.instruction_text: As a mathematical cartographer, your first task is to pinpoint the critical junctures. Click on the specific points or segments on the graph that exhibit discontinuity or non-differentiability.

feedback.on_correct: Excellent! You've correctly identified a key point on the graph.
feedback.on_incorrect: Not quite. Remember to look for specific characteristics like jumps, gaps, or sharp changes in direction. Try again.
feedback.on_completion: Fantastic! You've successfully identified all the critical points on the graph.

misconceptions.message: It looks like you clicked on a point that is both continuous and differentiable. Remember, a discontinuity means there's a break or jump in the graph, while a non-differentiable point might be continuous but have a sharp corner.

config.instruction_text: Excellent work identifying the breaks in the function's flow. Now that you've labeled the critical junctures, match each of the remaining segments to its correct description of continuity and differentiability.

feedback.on_correct: Perfect match! You've accurately described this segment's properties.
feedback.on_incorrect: That's not quite right. Carefully review the definitions of continuity and differentiability. A function can be continuous without being differentiable. Think about where the graph is smooth versus where it has sharp corners.
feedback.on_completion: Outstanding work! You've successfully matched all descriptions to their corresponding graph segments.

misconceptions.message: It seems there might be some confusion between continuous and differentiable. Remember, a function can be continuous (no breaks) but not differentiable (has a sharp corner or cusp). All differentiable functions are continuous, but not all continuous functions are differentiable.

config.instruction_text: Next, explore how functions map their domains to codomains. Drag each function's graph into the correct region on our mathematical map to classify it as Injective, Surjective, or Bijective.

feedback.on_correct: Excellent! This function is correctly classified as {category_label}.
feedback.on_incorrect: Not quite. Revisit the definitions: Injective (one-to-one) means each output comes from at most one input; Surjective (onto) means every output in the codomain is reached; Bijective means it's both. Which definition best fits this graph?
feedback.on_completion: Fantastic work! You've successfully classified all the functions based on their injective, surjective, and bijective properties.

misconceptions.message: It's common to mix these up! Remember, injective (one-to-one) means each output comes from at most one input, while surjective (onto) means every possible output in the codomain is achieved by at least one input. Bijective means it's both.

config.instruction_text: As a mathematical cartographer, your first task is to pinpoint the key landmarks. Drag and drop each label to its correct location on the function's graph.

feedback.on_correct: Excellent! You've correctly identified this key feature of the function.
feedback.on_incorrect: Not quite. Re-examine the definition of this feature and its visual characteristics on the graph. Does it represent a peak, a valley, a change in curvature, or a boundary the function approaches?
feedback.on_completion: Fantastic! You've successfully identified all the major landmarks of this function. Ready to describe them?

misconceptions.message: Remember, a critical point marks a local peak or valley where the function changes direction. An inflection point is where the *concavity* changes, not necessarily the direction of the function itself.
Vertical asymptotes occur where the function approaches infinity for a specific x-value. Horizontal asymptotes describe the function's end behavior as x approaches positive or negative infinity.
A graph can cross a horizontal asymptote for finite x-values; the asymptote only describes the function's end behavior as x approaches positive or negative infinity.

config.instruction_text: Now that you've labeled the function's landmarks, match each identified feature to its correct mathematical description or functional significance. Draw a line from the description to the corresponding point or line on the graph.

feedback.on_correct: That's a perfect match! You clearly understand the definition of this feature.
feedback.on_incorrect: Not quite. Carefully re-read both the description and the name of the feature. What specific characteristic does this description highlight?
feedback.on_completion: Outstanding! You've accurately matched all the descriptions to their respective graphical features. You've mastered identifying and defining these landmarks!

misconceptions.message: Remember, a critical point description focuses on local extrema and changes in function direction, while an inflection point description emphasizes changes in concavity.
The description of a horizontal asymptote focuses on the function's behavior as x approaches infinity, not necessarily a line the function can never cross.

descriptions.zone_continuous_&_differentiable_segment: This segment represents where the function's value changes smoothly and predictably, allowing for a consistently defined instantaneous rate of change at every point along its path.
descriptions.zone_continuous,_not_differentiable_segm: This segment shows where the function's value remains unbroken, yet its instantaneous rate of change undergoes an abrupt, non-smooth shift, preventing a unique tangent from being defined at specific points.

distractor_descriptions: This segment indicates a break in the function's path, where its value abruptly jumps or has a hole, making it impossible to trace without lifting your pen.

identificationPrompts.text: Click on the point where the function's path is abruptly broken, requiring a 'jump' or 'gap' to continue.
identificationPrompts.explanation: This point represents a discontinuity because the function value abruptly changes, creating a gap or jump in the graph, meaning it cannot be drawn without lifting the pen.

identificationPrompts.text: Click on the point where the function's smoothness is interrupted, forming a sharp corner or a vertical tangent, making it impossible to define a unique slope.
identificationPrompts.explanation: This point is non-differentiable because the graph forms a sharp corner (or cusp/vertical tangent), meaning the derivative (slope) from the left does not match the derivative from the right, or the tangent line is vertical.
